content: The "Small Business Procurement Improvement Act of 2012" aims to increase small business participation in multiple award contracts. The "Small Business Procurement Improvement Act of 2012" aims to increase small business participation in multiple award contracts by requiring the inclusion of small business concerns and making full use of set-aside programs. The "Small Business Procurement Improvement Act of 2012" requires agencies to increase small business participation in multiple award contracts through outreach programs and utilization of set-aside programs. The "Small Business Procurement Improvement Act of 2012" mandates agencies to enhance small business involvement in multiple award contracts by implementing outreach programs and set-aside programs. The Act defines a program to increase awareness, provide education and training, assist in contract listing, and track small business participation in multiple award contracts. The "Small Business Procurement Improvement Act of 2012" mandates agencies to enhance small business involvement in multiple award contracts through outreach and set-aside programs. SEC. 3 defines key terms for the Act. Section 3 of the Small Business Act (15 U.S.C. 632) is amended to include various types of contracts such as contracts under the Federal Supply Schedule program, multi-agency contracts, and Government-wide acquisition contracts for information technology. Additionally, the term 'blanket Purchase Agreement' is defined in the Act. The Small Business Act is amended to include different types of contracts like Federal Supply Schedule program contracts, multi-agency contracts, and Government-wide acquisition contracts for information technology. The Act also defines 'blanket Purchase Agreement' and 'basic Ordering Agreement'. SEC. 4 amends the Small Business Act to establish Government-wide goals for task orders and delivery orders placed against contracts awarded to small business concerns. SEC. 5 focuses on improvements to the Small Business Reserve. Section 15(j) of the Small Business Act is amended to increase the monetary threshold from $100,000 to $200,000. It also includes provisions for multiple award contracts, specifying regulations to ensure correct size standards are applied to each task order. The Administrator of the General Services Administration will ensure correct size standards, non-manufacturer rule, and subcontracting provisions are implemented at the task order level, and that electronic ordering systems display accurate size information for small businesses. SEC. 6. Small Business Representation on the Federal Acquisition Regulatory Council. Amends Section 1302(b)(1) of title 41, United States Code to include the Administrator of the Small Business Administration on the council. In case of an equal vote, the Administrator of the Office of Federal Procurement Policy will have the deciding vote.
